comments.commentBody: Some of these graph spikes have more to do with phone cams catching what has been happening for decades. This is an irresponsible comment, in the extreme, though it probably reflects the attitudes of many.  Which community is more "fed up" I wonder?  The whites who see crime as a racial problem (like you seem to), or blacks who see members of their communities killed when under arrest for petty crimes, and out of all proportion to the threat they pose when encountering police?  Which community is more "racist"?  The issue of how to deal with crime, and in what communities the problem is worst, should be considered separately from the use of deadly force.  And need I mention that there are plenty of affluent folk who break more serious laws, and are not indicted, let alone suffocated or gunned down in cold blood?  Some whites may be "fed up" but if I were black I'd be starting a revolution.  Maybe if you'd just written "crime" I'd have more sympathy for your point of view, but you didn't.  You wrote "black crime."

If the lower hours is due to local clients (as opposed to simply lying), then not everybody can do that. Someone is going to have to travel or deal with the time-consuming clients or projects. It's not clear that this report shows that everyone could reduce their hours, just a few.

It's disappointing to see the author misunderstanding the meaning of this study.  The conclusion is not that people can generally do better work with less hours.  The example they gave are men who took advantage of their personal situation (or designed their schedule in a favorable way).  Not everyone, however, is able to set up their consulting clients close to home.  For the men at these companies that can't do that, long hours are still a necessity of the job.  I fully agree that men (and women) are better off taking the family time they need when their schedules allow, without drawing attention to it.  It's just a mistake to think that everyone at these companies will be able to do the same thing.  Someone still needs to work with the out of town clients.

Since crime rates are declining across the board one would expect that if the correlation were to crime rates one would see an overall decline in these incidents.  Of course what makes it very difficult to actually disentangle these numbers is the fact that the crime rate is to a significant extent caused by aggressive policing.  That is, police will report criminal activity or charge people for the same activity differently based on their race (a well recorded phenomena in the war on drugs).

Without equitable enforcement, crime rates are dubious evidence of more crime.  Seems to me blacks are more likely to be stopped, arrested, and even killed or injured by police.  Crime rates likely reflect that, rather more crime per se.
Overly aggressive policing correlates to race or to neighborhood crime rates?

If the Feds had the resources to investigate all the members of the NY state legislature there wold be many more members found to be operating outside the law.

Here's a simple solution --- every politician MUST face re-election, say every 4 years. This will assure the process such that if the public and mass media determine the candidate isn't fit for office, they can simply vote them out.

But when the mass media and the public vote in the same thieves over and over again, well, just give the people what they asked for!

Time to move on. If a person enjoys being hoodwinked by corruption, let them continue to do so.
